title: Elland Park Wood Walking Route

images.title: Richard Kay / Public Footpath in Elland Park Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Public Footpath in Elland Park Wood. This is just one part of a network of paths in the woods; it leads steeply downhill. The path is sunken through use and erosion, not helped by a motorcyclist, who has left a track. In the foreground the natural ground is exposed - small fragments of sandstone in sandy clay. The leaf litter is predominantly oak.

images.title: Richard Kay / Elland Park Wood from Park Nook, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Elland Park Wood from Park Nook. The photo is taken from the public footpath heading north from the north-west corner of the woods. The 1:25,000 OS sheet shows the relatively new triangle of woodland, closest to the camera, whereas the 1:50,000 series has yet to be updated in this respect.

images.title: Richard Kay / Gateposts in Elland Park Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gateposts in Elland Park Wood. There is no sign of a nearby wall or fence. The only visible feature is the footpath, following the line of the posts.

images.title: Richard Kay / Public Footpath to Park Nook, through Elland Park Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Public Footpath to Park Nook, through Elland Park Wood. This footpath is well used and easy to follow. Note the diagonal transverse line of masonry in the foreground, to catch rain water and minimise surface erosion. The woodland is predominantly oak but holly bushes appear to be taking over.

images.title: Richard Kay / Narrow Boat on the Calder & Hebble Navigation at Elland Park Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Narrow Boat on the Calder & Hebble Navigation at Elland Park Wood The photo is taken at the back of the Colliers' Arms Public House. The canal was built in 1770 by John Smeaton, founder of the Society of Civil Engineers, later to become the Institution of Civil Engineers.The canal is a 'broad' canal, although most present-day craft are narrow boats such as the one in the picture.

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Track across the Cromwell Bottom Nature Reserve, Elland (1), via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Track across the Cromwell Bottom Nature Reserve, Elland

description: These woods in Halifax have some nice walking trails and pretty bluebells in the springtime. The site is located just to the south east of the town centre and consists of a network of footpaths and oak woodland. The woods are positioned just north of the Calder and Hebble Navigation Canal. You can easily extend your walk by picking up the towpath and heading east to the Cromwell Bottom Nature Reserve.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: On the north eastern outskirts of Halifax you'll find the splendid Shibden Park. The popular park has miles of trails with woodland, lakes, gardens and water features to enjoy. From here you can also explore the lovely hills and countryside of the Shibden Valley and Shibden Dale. To the north of the town there's some remote Pennine Moor walks around Ogden Water and Warley Moor Reservoir.

display_address: West Lane, Siddal, Southowram, Calderdale, West Yorkshire, England, HX3 9TU, United Kingdom
